oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cats and Goat Whey Associated with Toxoplasma gondii Infection in Pigs
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Meerburg, B.G.
Van Riel, J.W.
Cornelissen, J.B.
Kijlstra, A.
Mul, M.F.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Food security, food quality and human health
Pigs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In organic livestock production systems, farm-management factors are thought to play an important role in the on-farm prevalence of Toxoplasma gondii. Serological results and the results of an HACCP analysis were combined to determine important risk factors for the prevalence of this protozoan parasite. Mathematical analysis demonstrated that feeding goat whey to pigs and the presence of a high number of cats were positively correlated to T. gondii seroprevalence in pigs. Not covering roughage and the farmers' assumption that pigs can come into contact with cat feces also showed a positive relationship. In order to decrease the risk of T. gondii infecting their pigs, farmers should limit the access and number of cats on their farms and refrain from feeding goat whey to their pigs.
